3.67.text:
Until the last decade of the 15th century,
the islands at the Edge of the World were

8.00.text:
as far West as it was believed human beings
could travel without falling over the Edge.

13.12.text:
The leader of the Western World, the United
States, had not even been discovered.

65.19.text:
So far in this series, we have employed the
expression, 'East and West.' This is common

71.21.text:
today, and is often used in the context of
East versus West, whether the East be China,

76.80.text:
or Iran, or North Korea. There has been a
kind of text, variously subliminal and frequently

84.00.text:
overt, in the West since the Renaissance that
European - Western - culture was superior

89.91.text:
to Eastern culture.
This gained purchase in the nineteenth century

94.60.text:
as the Muslim Turkish or Ottoman Empire, whose
capital was Istanbul, faltered in the the

100.49.text:
Balkans, the Near and Middle East; and as
scholars like Jacob Burckhardt, Thomas Carlyle,

107.01.text:
Fran�ois Guizot enjoyed the acclaim of readers
of their best-selling books on the march of

111.95.text:
Western cuture and values. Indeed, Istanbul
was marked in nineteenth-century atlases as

118.69.text:
Constantinople, its former Christian name.
A sense of Western superiority was likewise

125.45.text:
engendered by the developments in agriculture
and industry in Europe from the late seventeenth

131.33.text:
century, although it has since been calculated
that, in 1800, Chinese manufacturing output

137.95.text:
was greater than the rest of the world put
together.

142.11.text:
By the 19th century and for much of the twentieth,
perhaps the most significant spur to the sense

146.82.text:
of European complacency was imperialism. The
Islands at the Edge of the World, more than

152.37.text:
any other Western state, had an empire that
spanned the world.

157.98.text:
Imperialism exported European authority and
ideas - Christian ideas most of all - to the

164.44.text:
world. The first Europeans to sail the Atlantic
arrived, in 1492, at the island of Hispaniola

171.58.text:
(now divided between the countries of Haiti
and the Dominican Republic). The three Spanish

177.38.text:
ships that made this voyage were under the
command of Christopher Columbus, who was born

182.49.text:
in Genoa, Italy.
Sharing the Iberian peninsula with the Spanish

187.29.text:
were the Portuguese who had sailed round the
Cape of Good Hope, at the tip of southern

191.62.text:
Africa, as far as India by the 1480s.
The Portuguese had a ruler at this time, whose

199.50.text:
epithet is just. He was Henry the Navigator.
His principal adventurer, the first European

207.33.text:
to see Table Mountain, was Vasco da Gama.
The Portuguese soon joined the Spanish in

213.76.text:
America, where these two Iberian monarchies
conquered most of the central and southern

218.44.text:
continent in the 16th century, carving out
and ruthlessly exploiting valuable empires.

224.10.text:
And these avowedly Christian rulers supplemented
the growing labour shortage in their new American

230.71.text:
territories by the importation of slaves from
Africa, the Slave Trade becoming a valuable

238.15.text:
Dutch, French, and British followed the North
Atlantic route from the seventeenth century,

244.63.text:
subduing the indigenous peoples of the modern
United States and Canada.

249.97.text:
Christian tsars conquered more than two million
square miles of south Asia, continuing a policy

255.05.text:
inaugurated by Ivan IV (the Terrible) in the
16th century, picked up again in the 18th

261.34.text:
century by Peter the Great and Catherine the
Great, who conquered her way south to the

265.60.text:
Crimea and the Black Sea.
By 1900, there were few areas of the world

271.67.text:
that were not part of some European empire,
or European successor state, like the United

276.92.text:
States. Even the Germans and the Belgians
joined in the 'Scramble for Africa' in the

282.20.text:
closing years of the 19th century, the King
of the Belgians owning, as his private property,

287.76.text:
the richest plum of them all, the Congo, covering
one and a half million square miles.

295.08.text:
By the end of the Great War, in 1918, the
Empire of China had been dissolved and the

300.66.text:
new republic was at civil war that would not
end until 1949. The Russian Revolution of

307.68.text:
1917 had consolidated most of the tsarist
empire to become the Soviet Empire of Marshal

313.42.text:
Stalin in the 1930s.
The last non-Western empire, Turkey, was reduced

319.81.text:
to Asia Minor, the British and the French
hacking off Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, and

325.35.text:
Iraq for themselves. The few remaining independent
states - Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia, Iran, Afghanistan,

334.00.text:
Thailand - fell into some Western power's
sphere of influence.

339.65.text:
Latin America had become the backyard of the
United States whose governments propped up

344.66.text:
puppet dictatorships in the last century.
The only eastern country to survive and prosper

350.63.text:
was the Empire of Japan, but I use 'eastern'
here rather more in a geographical sense.

357.46.text:
It does not fit into my conception of the
East and the West, whose last unquestioned

362.44.text:
cultural triumph in Britain was probably Sir
Kenneth Clarke's television series - Civilization

371.13.text:
That preamble is well outside our period,
but if we are to understand anything about

375.87.text:
our present, we need to have a sense of the
strands that reach down to us from the past.

381.34.text:
The islands at the Edge of the World in the
so-called Dark Ages were part of a much larger

387.03.text:
world, and these old links have only fairly
recently received more recognition, especially

391.88.text:
from people like Melvyn Bragg and Andrew Marr
on BBC Radio 4.

397.50.text:
The impetus for a cultural and militarist
war against the East was initiated in 1095,

403.19.text:
by a resurgent Papacy, under Pope Urban II
at Clermont Ferrand, France, who declared

410.62.text:
Holy War against the Muslims in Palestine.
This was the First Crusade and you can see,

417.36.text:
in the 2003 attack on Iraq, that Western zeal
has hardly diminished since Pope Urban. It

424.32.text:
has been rightly said that societies are not
made - they grow.

432.83.text:
The proposition of East versus West goes back
at least 2,500 years, and is attributed to

443.28.text:
the Father of History, the Greek writer Herodotus,
who lived in the fifth century BC. He was

450.13.text:
probably born in Halicarnassus (now Bodrum,
south-west Turkey) in about 484BC, which was

457.55.text:
then part of the Persian Empire. (From now
on, we shall call Iran by its common historical

463.29.text:
name of Persia).
He travelled through much of the Persian Empire

468.80.text:
- through Asia Minor to Syria, to Mesopotamia
with its great city of Babylon (described

473.81.text:
in the Old Testament Book of Daniel), as far
as Susa, the ancient Persian capital.

479.55.text:
He visited Egypt which, as today, still stuns
foreign visitors, and reached Aswan in the

485.41.text:
south: the pharaohs had been conquered by
King Cambyses of Persia in the late 500s BC.

492.66.text:
Much of book two and all of the third book
of his nine-book History are devoted to this

497.57.text:
fabulous land.
He went to Thrace and Macedonia, also Persian

502.67.text:
possessions, and round the north coast of
the Black Sea where there were Greek outposts.

508.88.text:
He seems to have lived in or near Athens on
at east two occasions, but probably had his

513.93.text:
home in Thurii, a Greek town in southern Italy.
His History was published very soon after

519.98.text: his death at Thurii in about 425BC.

523.86.text:
It is not known when he undertook his journeys,
but they would have taken years. Why he made

530.73.text:
his travels, wrote his history - it is vastly
more than a travelogue - and structured it

535.36.text:
is unknown. That he was inquisitive, courageous,
and a great observer cannot be doubted.

542.17.text:
He narrates the Greek-Persian 30-year war
from 499BC, that includes the famous battles

549.46.text:
of Marathon, Thermopylae, and Salamis. He
is interested to know how a king of Persia

555.70.text:
could weld together as one, and command, Medes,
Persians, and other races in fleets, and armies

561.81.text:
that may have numbered a million troops, more
than 10 times the complement of the British

566.67.text:
Army today.
He tells us of King Xerxes' rages, one of

571.62.text:
which was about the Hellespont - a stretch
of water in the north Aegean. This was so

577.45.text:
rough that it delayed his army reaching land,
across a bridge of boats, and the king sentenced

582.72.text:
the water to 300 strokes of the lash, which
'punishment' was carried out with great formality.

589.09.text:
He also tells us how Xerxes watched from a
throne on a hill as his fleet was defeated

595.16.text:
at Salamis - on another occasion, how the
Persian ruler wept about the brevity of life

601.04.text: as his men went into battle.

604.04.text:
To Herodotus, it seems almost miraculous that
the Greeks won against such organized aggression.

610.36.text:
They fought as individual city states and
kings, and pulled through because of the mistakes

615.82.text:
of their enemies - not perhaps unlike the
capture of Troy, as told by Homer in the Iliad.

622.44.text:
In this heroic poem, the Greek leaders are
constantly arguing among themselves, but prevail

628.32.text:
after 10 years because of a clever ruse - the
Trojan Horse. The excellent Professor Bettany

635.60.text:
Hughes has recently proposed that the Iliad
can. in fact, be interpreted as an anti-war

644.74.text:
His travels into Persia may have been a quest
to understand the difference between the disjunctive

649.74.text:
Greeks and the organized Persia Empire: the
East and the West. He describes the politics

657.46.text:
of the Greek leaders who took part in the
war against the Persians. Essentially, this

661.80.text:
boiled down to democratic Athens and authoritarian
Sparta.

667.43.text:
Athenian democracy was a very limited affair,
in which all women and most men had no role.

673.28.text:
Interestingly, Spartan women could own their
own property and around this time, it is estimated,

679.17.text:
40 per cent of Spartan land was held by women.
No surprise, then, that Herodotus was accused

685.24.text:
by Athenians as 'the father of lies.' For
Herodotus, perhaps this Greek-Persian war

691.99.text:
was about the absolutist Persian East, in
which the merest whim of a king was obeyed,

697.48.text:
and the Greek West was about some sense of
popular Law.

700.93.text:
For, despite occasional dictators, like Draco,
they were elected and they could be got rid

706.87.text:
of. A nugget: Draco drew up a law code that
was so severe that it has entered modern English

713.62.text:
in the adjective, draconian. Herodotus is
uniquely devoid of racial prejudice. He is

720.82.text:
perceptive, critical, and has a profound feel
for human nature.

726.14.text:
At about the same time that Herodotus was
writing, what are now known as the Elgin Marbles

730.75.text:
- ninety-two sculptures, once painted - were
installed in the freize of the Partheon, at

736.12.text:
Athens. They depict the Greek war of survival
against the Persians, and also the wars between

741.23.text:
Athens and Sparta.
The Persians are represented as the wild creatures,

746.51.text:
some as centaurs, half man, half horse. The
Marbles are are the first plastic representation

752.70.text:
of the East-West fight-to-the-death of the
day. The Greeks, under the king of Macedonia,

759.49.text:
would break out of their small territory about
a century after Herodotus, and overthrow the

764.93.text:
Persian Empire.
That great adventure would be led by Alexander

769.32.text:
the Great, who carried Greek culture far and
wide, and whose successors would make permanent

775.29.text:
the foundation of Western or Greek philosophy,
literature, jurisprudence, science, geometry,

782.23.text:
medicine - etcetera - first and importantly,
in the Roman Empire.

788.07.text:
Herodotus has been in print almost from the
inception of printing, in Germany, in the

791.79.text:
15th century. He is in paperback, and you
don't have to be a scholar to read and enjoy

798.78.text:
While the East under Byzantine emperors and
Baghdad caliphs developed Greek-Roman culture,

805.50.text:
the West laboured under the obscurantism of
the Roman Church. We shall begin to see why
